cards.title: Taylor Swift / After the Apple royalties U-turn, is she most powerful woman in music?
cards.rawTitle: After the Apple royalties U-turn, is she most powerful woman in music?

item.title: Apple royalties U-turn: is Taylor Swift the most powerful woman in music?
item.trailText: Viewed as an advocate for artists and a game-changer, almost no other pop star could have made the corporate behemoth roll over
item.standFirst: Viewed as an advocate for artists and a game-changer, almost no other pop star could have made the corporate behemoth roll over
item.body:
“We hear you @taylorswift13,” Apple’s senior vice-president of internet services, Eddy Cue tweeted. “Apple will always make sure that artist [sic] are paid.”

It was the company’s response to an open letter from singer-songwriter Taylor Swift to her 59 million Twitter followers. She had announced that she would withhold her current album, 1989, from the corporate behemoth’s new streaming service, Apple Music, because it would not be paying royalties to artists during the service’s first three months.

Related: Apple Music to pay royalties during free trial: 'We hear you Taylor Swift'

Apple’s subsequent climbdown – the company claims it had already been considering it after being pressurised by independent labels – is a victory for musicians, who now stand to be paid an as-yet-undisclosed royalty (rival service Spotify pays a lordly $0.006 to $0.0084 per stream).

Yet it is a bigger victory for Swift, who in the last 12 months joined an elite group of artists who wield considerable clout in the music industry.

Her net worth has been estimated at $200m (£125m) by entertainment website Vulture. Her wealth – derived from record sales and touring, as well as her own fragrance range and property holdings – gives her the luxury of not having to care about putting bigwig noses out of joint. And she uses that power.

She has form with streaming companies: last autumn, she pulled her entire catalogue from Spotify in a protest against its royalty rate, and urged others to do the same. She says musicians and producers queued to thank her for taking a stand.

If she had denied Apple Music access to 1989 – which undoubtedly would have led to other artists following suit – the resulting Swift-shaped void would have seen the service launch without one of the year’s biggest-selling records.

In its first week of release last October, the album sold nearly 1.3m copies in the US alone, and is now approaching 9m sales worldwide. Overall, Swift’s five studio albums have sold 40m copies globally.

Viewed as both an advocate for artists and a game-changer – almost no other pop star could have made Apple Music roll over – the 25-year-old Pennsylvanian is arguably the world’s most powerful female music star. The other contender for that status, Beyoncé, is almost more brand than human being these days, promoting her new 22 Days vegan diet programme with exactly the same tirelessness as her feminist message.

Swift, therefore, has a better shot at winning hearts and minds. Last November, Time magazine and Bloomberg Businessweek ran cover stories to that effect: “Taylor Swift is the music industry,” said Bloomberg, while Time headlined its piece “The Power of Taylor Swift”.

Her 10-year career has reached a junction where critical approval, commercial success and cultural impact have coalesced. She is an influencer – the sort of celebrity who can say: “My hope for the future, not just in the music industry, but in every young girl I meet … is that they all realise their worth and ask for it,” and know she will be listened to.

Teenage fans adore her – it would be hard to be 14 years old and not see smart, talented, beautiful Swift as an aspirational figure. The music media revere her, too, for creating unstintingly honest music in a pop framework (which can be a bit shrill and preoccupied by vindictive feelings toward ex-boyfriends, but it gives a much greater insight into her inner workings than you would get from the perpetually guarded Beyoncé).

Awards clutter her mantelpiece; presumably, she put up a new shelf to accommodate her most recent haul of eight Billboard gongs. And she has become a handy person to know, helping her friend Ed Sheeran before he broke big in America.

Related: Taylor Swift: ‘Sexy? Not on my radar'

She is also different in having started as a country singer before successfully switching to pop. When her first album came out, she was 16 and had moved to Nashville to immerse herself in the country industry; nine years later, Country Taylor is a faint memory.

The one thing she lacks – and, to judge by her lyrics, it irks her – is a mutually satisfying relationship. “I go on too many dates, but I can’t make them stay, at least that’s what people say,” she sang on the 2014 worldwide top-five single Shake it Off. The lyric was a neat send-up of the gossip magazine perception that there must be something wrong with her rather than her men, who have included One Direction singer Harry Styles and, currently, producer Calvin Harris.

Moreover, the crux of the song is the defiant line: “Just think, while you’ve been getting down and out about the liars and the dirty, dirty cheats of the world, you could’ve been getting down to this sick beat.” (The phrase “this sick beat” became an internet meme, and Taylor subsequently applied to register the phrase as a trademark in the US.)

Yet there are also songs such as the bitter We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together, her first No 1 hit, which was said to be inspired by a relationship with songwriter John Mayer. For all her “this sick beat” bravado, there’s bottomless venom in the couplet: “You would hide away and find your peace of mind, with some indie record that’s much cooler than mine.”

And a “feud” with singer Katy Perry – who apparently tried to hire some of Swift’s dancers – also roused her wrath to the extent that she wrote a furious track called Bad Blood. That also reached No 1. The video features a vengeful gang of her famous friends, among them actor Lena Dunham, model Cara Delevingne and rapper Kendrick Lamar, who train her up to attack a female adversary. Two things are gleaned from it: Swift’s reach extends well beyond the pop world, and she is in danger of being seen as a bully.

Still, she is an interesting person to have around. Pop is currently full of strong female characters, of whom she is easily the most watchable. It would be satisfying to see her use her power for good.

cards.title: Rachel de Thame / 'I was banned from breastfeeding at Chelsea flower show'
cards.rawTitle: 'I was banned from breastfeeding at Chelsea flower show'

item.title: Rachel de Thame: 'I was banned from breastfeeding at Chelsea flower show'
item.trailText: Gardener’s World presenter tells Radio Times about juggling motherhood and her career – and an incident at the horticultural event
item.standFirst: Gardener’s World presenter tells Radio Times about juggling motherhood and her career – and an incident at the horticultural event
item.body:
The Gardener’s World presenter Rachel de Thame has revealed that she was once prevented from breastfeeding at the Chelsea flower show while filming.

The 53-year-old model turned gardening expert said she had been juggling motherhood and her career in front of the camera well until the moment she “wasn’t allowed” to breastfeed at the flower show.

“[T]here was one occasion when I was filming at the Chelsea flower show and I wasn’t allowed to breast-feed,” she told the Radio Times in an interview published on Tuesday.

“I’m an earth mother. I liked being pregnant and giving birth and breastfeeding. Up until that point, the job I was doing was working really well with juggling the kids, but not then.”

De Thame did not specify when the incident happened or in which capacity she was filming, and gave no other details . She became a presenter on BBC2’s flagship gardening series in 1999 and has presented the BBC1 and BBC2 coverage of horticultural shows including Chelsea. She has two children aged 26 and 23 from her first marriage to Stephen Colover and two daughters from her second marriage who are now 11 and nine.

De Thame told the magazine that she “absolutely” thought women and men were equal in the world of horticulture and design, but pointed out that there had been a gender disparity at Chelsea this year. “[H]aving said there are as many opportunities for men as there are for women, I did notice that there weren’t many show gardens designed this year at Chelsea and I am not sure what that is about,” she added.

“Maybe the same issues that affect women working in other spheres do affect women in horticulture. We have babies. We are not available for full-time work. It’s tricky but we definitely need both male and female designers in order to get balance.”

cards.title: Europe's oldest man, Nazar Singh from Sunderland, dies aged 111
cards.rawTitle: Europe's oldest man, Nazar Singh from Sunderland, dies aged 111

item.title: Europe's oldest man, Nazar Singh from Sunderland, dies age 111
item.trailText: Huge family played a part in him living so long, says one of his 34 grandchildren and 63 great-grandchildren
item.standFirst: Huge family played a part in him living so long, says one of his 34 grandchildren and 63 great-grandchildren
item.body:
He put his longevity down to a loving family, good food and a drop of whisky every night.

Nazar Singh, a great-grandfather from Sunderland, who at 111 was believed to be Europe’s oldest man, died in India on the eve of Father’s Day, after travelling over to spend time with family.

He had recently celebrated his birthday, sending pictures back to Britain that showed him marking the event with a pint of lager and a whisky chaser.

Born on 8 June 1904, Singh lived through the great depression, two world wars, and the independence and partition of India. He moved to England in 1965, living first in Walsall, West Midlands, where he worked in a foundry, then retiring to the north-east in 1989, living with one of his nine children.

With 34 grandchildren and 63 great-grandchildren, Singh was always surrounded by family, said his grandson, Harvinder Gill, 31. “He was an incredible chap,” Gill, from Ashbrooke, Sunderland, said. “He has lived a very happy and fulfilling life.

“For the past few weeks he has been suffering with a few illnesses. He has had pneumonia but he was a fighter. Unfortunately, his time has passed. It was early hours on Saturday, just before Father’s Day.”

Singh was born on a farm in Punjab where he helped his family grow sugar cane, cotton, corn, wheat and later chilli, peanuts, potatoes and rice. He outlived his wife, Narajan Kaur, who died 12 years ago, as well as his two sisters and four brothers.

Even into old age he kept his love of the outdoors – only giving up gardening at 107. He enjoyed drinking milk and almond oil, regularly ate fruit and had a nightly drop of whisky.

After his 110th birthday, he was quoted in media reports as saying: “I feel very good and very happy. I still feel fit and strong. I pray to the lord to take me when he wants to.” He put his longevity down to “good family, good food and happiness”.

“Eat healthy food and look after each other,” he said. “Family need to look after their elders.”

Singh had returned to India in January, where he was being cared for by his two eldest sons. But he kept in touch regularly with relatives in the UK by phone. Despite his age, he still had perfect hearing.

His age was never confirmed by Guinness World Records and he had no birth certificate. But he was sent a letter by the Queen on his 100th birthday, and every subsequent birthday.

cards.title: Dapper Laughs / Comedian's journey to the bottom continues with copycat website
cards.rawTitle: Comedian's journey to the bottom continues with copycat website

item.title: Dapper Laughs continues his journey to the bottom with copycat website
item.trailText: The comedian infamous for rape jokes and other hilarity has established DappsDaily.com – which appears to be lifting content wholesale
item.standFirst: The comedian infamous for rape jokes and other hilarity has established DappsDaily.com – which appears to be lifting content wholesale
item.byline: Hannah Jane Parkinson and Jasper Jackson
item.body:
Dapper Laughs’ listicle website, DappsDaily.com, has had the briefest stint online after a Guardian investigation revealed it to be rife with content copied word-for-word from a number of different websites, including Metro.co.uk and PopSugar.

The comedian, aka Daniel O’Reilly, is most famous for releasing a single called “Proper Moist”, making jokes about homeless people, telling a woman she was “gagging for a rape” and having an ITV show pulled after public outcry.

Not content with dragging the murdered Charlie Hebdo journalists into his argument that his freedom of speech to make jokes about “a cracking set of balls” and simulate sex with a table had been “violated”, he decided to try his hand at internet publishing with a website aping popular lists and viral pieces.

Unfortunately, “aping” isn’t quite the right term, more … wholesale copying. Many of the articles on DappsDaily.com were apparently lifted, word for word, from other sites.

For instance, a DappsDaily.com piece entitled “Nine Reasons We All Love Emma Watson” appears to be a direct copy of an article found on uberpunch.com, and also grabmeme.com.

An article about a man complaining about “crooked bread slices” seems lifted from a piece published the day before at viralthread.com.

Another, 10 reasons to never date a man with a big penis, matches a piece written by Yvette Caster for Metro.co.uk. An article on Orange is the New Black star Ruby Rose is eerily similar exactly the same as this Melissa Chapman piece on viralthread.com.

Other articles include pieces seemingly lifted from boredpanda.com, including one about a husband giving his ex-wife half of his assets. None of the pieces credit original sources.

The entire website seems to be a rehash of unitrending.co.uk – as evidenced by, er, a Unitrending logo still being used as the website favicon, and page title. DappsDaily.com’s source code appears to confirm this link.

Unitrending said they had submitted the layout of their site for public use.

In an email to the Guardian, a Unitrending spokesman wrote: “I can’t view that site [DappsDaily.com], but we use the ‘newspaper’ open source template where you can download different versions of the template which is why it probably looked the same.”

This would not explain why articles on O’Reilly’s site appeared to have been lifted from other sources.

A statement on DappsDaily.com reads: “We’re always looking for high-quality content, if you feel you have something worth a look, get in touch.”

So far, high-quality content includes Girl Gives Guys A Snapchat Guide To Taking Dick Pics and Boyfriend Discovers Something Inside His Girlfriend. What a time to be alive.

We also contacted O’Reilly on Twitter and via email – a Hotmail address, because apparently this is 2001.

O’Reilly responded to the Guardian’s questions via Twitter, stating that content had been sent into the site via the original authors – a claim which one author refuted. Minutes later, DappsDaily.com was taken offline and replaced with a 404 error.

The cache of the site can still be viewed here, while the Guardian has taken screenshots of its content.

The deputy editor of viralthread.com, Melissa Chapman, has since responded to reject O’Reilly’s claims that she ever gave permission or submitted her content to the site. In comment to the Guardian, Chapman wrote:

“I expect stories to cross over when it comes to online news content but to take a piece and post it word for word and (I assume) make money from it seems very wrong to me.

“I especially don’t like the fact that Dapper has put his name to my words since I’d never want to associate myself with his quite shocking views, especially towards women.

“I can confirm I didn’t give Dapper any permission to use viral thread content, nor would I have done if he’d of asked. I wasn’t aware his website had used it until I read your piece.”

We await the appearance of O’Reilly in a black polo neck on Newsnight to explain this one.

• Ashton Kutcher’s A+ viral content site accused of plagiarism

cards.title: Ralph Fiennes / Director role but not lead in Rudolf Nureyev drama
cards.rawTitle: Director role but not lead in Rudolf Nureyev drama

item.title: Ralph Fiennes to direct – but not star in – Rudolf Nureyev drama
item.trailText: Tale of iconic Russian dancer and famous defector will be based on a screenplay by David Hare, writer of the Oscar-winning 2008 film The Reader – but unlike Fiennes’ first two films as director, he won’t also take the leading role
item.standFirst: Tale of iconic Russian dancer and famous defector will be based on a screenplay by David Hare, writer of the Oscar-winning 2008 film The Reader – but unlike Fiennes’ first two films as director, he won’t also take the leading role
item.body:
Ralph Fiennes will direct a film detailing a major incident in the life of legendary Russian ballet dancer and famous defector Rudolf Nureyev, reports Screen Daily.

The untitled drama will be based on a screenplay by David Hare, the British writer of 2008 Nazi-themed romance The Reader. Fiennes, who will not take the starring role, has secured rights to Julie Kavanagh’s authorised biography Nureyev: The Life and hopes to shoot in 2016.

Related: Ralph Fiennes: five best moments

Nureyev defected from the Soviet Union to the West in 1961, despite the best efforts of the KGB. It is not clear which period of his life the film will cover, but there are many to choose from: the defection itself, which took place in Paris with the help of the French police and a Parisian socialite friend named Clara Saint; his tempestuous love affair with Erik Bruhn, soloist at the Royal Danish Ballet; his forays into film via Ken Russell’s Valentino in 1967, and with Nastassja Kinski in 1983’s Exposed; his stage partnerships with dancers Margot Fonteyn and Yvette Chauviré, or his 1983 appointment as director of the Paris Opera Ballet.

Fiennes has history working with Hare, having starred in The Reader as a German lawyer who once had an affair with an older woman, Hanna Schmitz, later discovered to have previously worked as a Nazi concentration camp guard. Kate Winslet won the best actress Oscar at the 2009 awards for her role in Stephen Daldry’s film.

The Nureyev drama is being put together at BBC Films by Philomena producer Gabrielle Tana and former Pathe executive Francois Ivernel. Fiennes will next be seen in front of the camera as spymaster M in the new James Bond film, Spectre, which debuts in November. He has directed two previous films, a 2011 adaptation of Shakespeare’s Coriolanus and 2013’s Charles Dickens biopic The Invisible Woman.

cards.title: Nile Rodgers goes busking on London's South Bank
cards.rawTitle: Nile Rodgers goes busking on London's South Bank

item.title: Nile Rodgers goes busking on London's South Bank
item.trailText: Chic star performs classics including Le Freak for a modest crowd and says he earned enough for a nice breakfast
item.standFirst: Chic star performs classics including Le Freak for a modest crowd and says he earned enough for a nice breakfast
item.body:
If you thought that busker you walked past on London’s South Bank on Monday morning was a little better than the usual fare, it’s because you may have been hearing a bona fide funk superstar.

Chic’s Nile Rodgers treated passersby to some of his classics beside the Thames – and kept his guitar case open for donations.

Initially unrecognisable in a wooly red hat, multicoloured scarf and camel jacket, he drew a modest crowd when he started singing Le Freak.

A few hours earlier he had played to tens of thousands of people at London’s Hyde Park.

He revealed on Twitter that he was familiar with street performance as he had been homeless earlier in his life. The 62-year-old is to headline a homeless charity gala next month.

Responding to tweets pointing out that his guitar case seemed empty, he wrote: “I know. But it got better by the end of my set! Then the coins were flowing.” He added: “I can afford a nice breakfast now.”

People who spotted him on the South Bank posted images on social media.

At Hyde Park this weekend Rodgers told the crowd that his work had given him the strength to overcome cancer.

Chic are releasing their first album in more than 20 years, called It’s About Time.

cards.title: Lemn Sissay / Poet beats Mandelson in race to be Manchester University chancellor
cards.rawTitle: Poet beats Mandelson in race to be Manchester University chancellor

item.title: Poet beats Peter Mandelson in race to be Manchester University chancellor
item.trailText: Lemn Sissay – poet, broadcaster and playwright – gets 7,131 votes, beating Hallé music director Sir Mark Elder and the Labour grandee to ceremonial post
item.standFirst: Lemn Sissay – poet, broadcaster and playwright – gets 7,131 votes, beating Hallé music director Sir Mark Elder and the Labour grandee to ceremonial post
item.body:
The Labour grandee Peter Mandelson has failed in his bid to become chancellor of Manchester University despite a concerted lobbying campaign, losing out to a poet from Wigan.

Lemn Sissay, a poet, broadcaster and playwright who grew up in care, was elected in an electronic vote by the university alumni with 7,131 votes. Afterwards, one of Sissay’s most vocal supporters described him as an “inspirer”, while Mandelson was a “conspirer”.

The electorate of 150,000 – comprising university staff, registered alumni and members of the general assembly – chose the award-winning poet from a shortlist of three.

Sir Mark Elder, music director of Manchester’s Hallé Orchestra, came second on 5,483. Mandelson, former EU trade commissioner and a key figure in Tony Blair’s government – nicknamed “the prince of darkness” for his political talents – came last on 5,269.

The Guardian understands Mandelson will be offered another lofty position at the university as a consolation prize – most likely honorary chair.

Despite denying to the Guardian back in March that he fancied becoming chancellor, Mandelson was already busy talking to key movers and shakers in Manchester to corral support.

His interest in the position was seen as further evidence of Manchester’s ascendance, the centre of what the other chancellor (George Osborne) calls his “northern powerhouse”.

After the general election, Mandelson gave a lecture at the university’s politics department and filmed a short video in which he said he wanted to be part of the university’s “success story”.

Sissay produced a rival video in which he performed a poem called Mercurial Graphene, a celebration of Manchester and the wonder substance discovered by scientists at the university.

After the poet’s victory was announced, Manchester author and DJ Dave Haslam, who was a vocal campaigner against Mandelson on social media, tweeted:

Team Mandelson insisted it did not “campaign” as much as give him a few introductions, but noted that there was a concerted anti-Mandelson campaign on social media run by “people in the shadows”.

“There’s something archly ironic for someone working on a campaign with Peter Mandelson to complain about others working in the shadows, but there you go. Not that I’m complaining,” said one of Mandelson’s supporters.

The election of a new ceremonial figurehead for the university followed the completion of the seven-year tenure of current chancellor, Tom Bloxham, the founder of the Manchester-based property development company Urban Splash. Sissay will take up his new role on 1 August and an installation ceremony will take place at the university in October.

Sissay is an associate artist at the Southbank Centre, patron of the Letterbox Club – which provides educational support for looked-after children - and fellow of the Foundling Museum. He is also the author of a series of books of poetry, alongside articles, records, radio documentaries, public art, and plays.

Brought up in Atherton, near Wigan, earlier this year Sissay made a series of programmes for BBC Manchester in which he claimed he was physically abused at a children’s home which is under investigation by police.

His allegations are among more than 40 complaints of historical sexual and physical abuse at the former Wood End assessment centre in Atherton. Hundreds of boys were sent there between the 1970s and the 1990s.

In 2012 one of Sissay’s poems was painted on the side of one of the university’s buildings on Oxford Road.

The university’s president and vice-chancellor, Professor Dame Nancy Rothwell, said: “The chancellor of the university, while a ceremonial office, brings with it significant ambassadorial responsibilities in helping to promote the university’s achievements worldwide, which Tom has done with enthusiasm and dedication throughout his time in office.

She added: “Each one of the nominees had excellent credentials and would have made a fine ambassador for the university.

“My warm and sincere congratulations go to Lemn on his election to be our next chancellor. I look forward to welcoming him to the university community and working with him to promote our ambitious plans over the coming years.”

Sissay said: “Reach for the top of the tree and you may get to the first branch, but reach for the stars and you’ll get to the top of the tree. My primary aim is to inspire and be inspired.

“I am proud to be chancellor of this fantastic university and extremely grateful to everyone who voted for me.”

Rothwell said she would be exploring with both Mandelson and Elder “other ways in which they may play a constructive role in supporting the university’s agenda going forward.”

Michael Taylor, a Manchester-based entrepreneur and member of the university’s alumni association who helped on Mandelson’s campaign, said: “I take some comfort from Nancy’s statement that a role for Peter on Team Manchester is in her thoughts and plans. It remains a truth acknowledged where it matters that Peter has much to contribute to Manchester.

“For all of us, that would be wonderful and I hope he has felt sufficiently encouraged and inspired to pursue that.”
